docs.lead_paragraph: Union leaders, academics and community activists plan to hold an unusual meeting in Washington today to begin mapping out a strategy to check Wal-Mart's growing power and to press the company to improve its wages and benefits. The meeting was organized largely because union leaders fear that Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest company, is pushing down wages and benefits, not just among retailers but throughout the economy.

headline.main: Some Critics Of Wal-Mart Joining Forces To Change It

docs.abstract: Union leaders, academics and community activists plan to hold unusual meeting in Washington to begin mapping out strategy to check Wal-Mart's growing power and to press company to improve its wages and benefits; meeting is organized because union leaders fear Wal-Mart Stores is pushing down wages and benefits, not just among retailers but throughout economy; Service Employees International Union president Andrew Stern convenes meeting, which will bring together union leaders, professors who have studied Wal-Mart and leaders of Acorn and other community groups; organizers also say Barbara Ehrenreich, author of Nickel and Dimed, account of making living as blue-collar worker, will attend; meeting will not focus on developing strategies to unionize Wal-Mart but rather on assessing Wal-Mart's influence on nation and on strategies to check Wal-Mart's downward pull on wages (M)
docs.snippet: Union leaders, academics and community activists plan to hold an unusual meeting in Washington today to begin mapping out a strategy to check Wal-Mart's growing power and to press the company to improve its wages and benefits.      The meeting was...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Mildred Fruhling and her husband lost their prescription drug coverage in 2001, they suddenly faced drug bills of $7,000 a year. Mrs. Fruhling, now 76, began scrambling to find discounts on the Internet, by mail order, from Canada and through free samples from her doctors. ''It's the only way I can continue to have some ease in my retirement,'' she said.

headline.main: 73 Options for Medicare Plan Fuel Chaos, Not Prescriptions

docs.abstract: Medicare has approved confusing array of competing drug discount cards for eligible participants to go into effect June 1; retirees of different income groups complain of incomprehension, interviews; cards are prelude to broad drug coverage set for 2006; are intended to provide discounts of 10 percent to 25 percent for participants who have no other prescription drug coverage; each card, which costs up to $30 a year, provides different discounts on different drugs and is accepted by different pharmacies; participants can chose only one; photo (M)
docs.snippet: When Mildred Fruhling and her husband lost their prescription drug coverage in 2001, they suddenly faced drug bills of $7,000 a year. Mrs. Fruhling, now 76, began scrambling to find discounts on the Internet, by mail order, from Canada and through...

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Boeing Manager Faces Federal Charges A former manager of Boeing was charged in a federal court with using documents stolen from Lockheed Martin to help Boeing win an important Pentagon rocket contract in 1998. The former manager, Larry Satchell, is the third Boeing employee to be implicated in a scheme that has turned into a financial and public relations debacle for Boeing. [Page C4.]
docs.snippet: Former Boeing Manager Faces Federal Charges  A former manager of Boeing was charged in a federal court with using documents stolen from Lockheed Martin to help Boeing win an important Pentagon rocket contract in 1998.       The former manager, Larry...

docs.lead_paragraph: Leigh Todd spent four years and $300,000 to have a baby. She saw 10 doctors and sought help at medical clinics in New York, Chicago and Las Vegas. And while Ms. Todd says she had no idea what she was in for when she began her quest, it did not take long before she was sucked into a world of tests and treatments, conventional and unconventional, doing whatever it took, paying as much as was asked.
docs.abstract: Number of assisted fertility attempts in United States has risen from 64,036 in 1996 to 107,587 in 2001 and fertility experts hold that increased options for infertile couples is part of reason; cost of treatments vary with in vitro fertilization using donor eggs running as high as $35,000 per attempt; there is concern that patients, desperate to have children, are vulnerable and often try even unproven methods to get pregnant; Leigh Todd's story of quest for baby discussed; Dr Mark V Sauer of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons contends that patients are basically well-informed about procedures and options; graph showing costs of various fertility options; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Denzel Washington may owe his life to Chris Palmer. Unlike Mr. Washington, who stars in 20th Century Fox's new action film ''Man on Fire,'' Mr. Palmer is not a Hollywood leading man. Balding, bearded and heavy-set, with a passing resemblance to Orson Welles, Mr. Palmer, 41, is director of risk control for the Albert G. Ruben unit of the insurance broker Aon; Ruben provides security for film studios.

headline.main: Making the World Safer, One Client at a Time

docs.abstract: Article on Albert G Ruben unit of insurance broker Aon, which provides security for film studios; Chris Palmer, who is director of risk control for Aon unit, comments; security measures taken by Albert G Ruben on set of Denzel Washington's film Man on Fire in Mexico detailed; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The push for legislation to legalize imports of prescription drugs is gaining momentum, with some major drugstore chains, a number of state attorneys general and several insurance companies endorsing the idea. Drug manufacturers remain adamantly opposed. But Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said last week that he believed that passage of legislation to allow imports of lower-cost medicines was inevitable.

headline.main: Support Is Growing for Legalizing Imports of Cheaper Drugs

docs.abstract: Push for legislation to legalize imports of prescription drugs is gaining momentum, with some major drugstore chains, some state attorneys general and several insurance companies endorsing idea; drug manufacturers remain adamantly opposed, but passage of bill is considered inevitable by Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson; CVS and Walgreens, two of nation's largest pharmacy chains, have given qualified endorsement to idea, saying commercial drug imports would be much safer than unregulated imports by individuals (M)
docs.snippet: The push for legislation to legalize imports of prescription drugs is gaining momentum, with some major drugstore chains, a number of state attorneys general and several insurance companies endorsing the idea.    Drug manufacturers remain adamantly...

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying the Bush administration had failed to react to spiraling health care premiums, Senator John Kerry vowed on Monday to cut those costs by about 10 percent, or $1,000, per family. ''Mine is a plan that will cut soaring premiums, cut the waste, cut the greed, and cut Americans a good deal,'' Mr. Kerry, the presumed Democratic presidential nominee, told several hundred people, of his proposal to have the federal government assume the responsibility for catastrophic care, a move intended to reduce health insurance costs.

headline.main: Faulting the Administration, Kerry Vows to Rein In Health Care Premiums

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry vows to cut health care premiums by 10 percent, or $1,000 per family, saying Bush administration has failed to react to spiraling costs; tells several hundred people in Edinboro, Pa, of his proposal to have federal government assume responsibility for catastrophic care, move intended to reduce health insurance costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Barry D. Laughlin, who manages the huge Navistar International truck factory here, does not even think of hiring more workers as production ramps up in a growing economy. ''We can go up in output in a lot of other ways before we have to add workers,'' Mr. Laughlin said during a recent tour of the giant elongated plant on the rural outskirts of this southern Ohio city, whose downtown streets display closed brick factory buildings on many blocks.

headline.main: Surge in Jobs Mostly Bypasses the Factory Floor

docs.abstract: Manufacturing employment is down nearly 3 million over last 44 months; 37,000 manufacturing jobs created so far represent minuscule contribution to 708,000 jobs generated over last three months across entire economy; manufacturers warn not expect much of job revival at their companies; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At one time, polite people never asked to look at their own medical records. To do so would indicate a lack of trust in your physician. Besides, doctors were so resistant to the practice that getting hold of your records could require a subpoena. But that way of thinking is a relic of old-fashioned medicine, as out of date as the house call and the black medical bag.

headline.main: How Patients Can Use the New Access to Their Medical Records

docs.abstract: Federal law, enacted in April 2003, now allows patients unfettered access to all medical records from doctors, hospitals and clinics; what to expect when searching records discussed; different procedures and possible fees for getting records described (M)
docs.snippet: At one time, polite people never asked to look at their own medical records. To do so would indicate a lack of trust in your physician. Besides, doctors were so resistant to the practice that getting hold of your records could require a subpoena.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As Newt Gingrich and Patrick Kennedy suggest, transforming the archaic state of the patient medical record into a coordinated modern information system will increase efficiency, improve care and save money.

headline.main: My Health File, Our Health System

docs.abstract: Dr Robert C Gorman letter agrees with Newt Gingrich and Patrick Kennedy (May 3 Op-Ed) that transforming archaic state of patient medical records into coordinated modern information system would increase efficiency, improve care and save money
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    As Newt Gingrich and Patrick Kennedy suggest, transforming the archaic state of the patient medical record into a coordinated modern information system will increase efficiency, improve care and save money.
